{"error":"OK","limit":100,"offset":0,"number_of_page_results":5,"number_of_total_results":5,"status_code":1,"results":[{"api_detail_url":"https:\/\/www.giantbomb.com\/api\/accessory\/3000-1\/","date_added":"2008-05-09 10:18:16","date_last_updated":"2010-11-01 12:58:54","deck":"The DualShock controller brought dual analog control and force feedback to the original PlayStation and has been used by Sony ever since.","description":"

The DualShock is the iconic and critically acclaimed PlayStation<\/a> controller on which Sony<\/a> has based all of its subsequent controller designs. The DualShock was developed by Sony for use with the original PlayStation and released in Japan<\/a> in 1997. The PlayStation's original controller lacked analog control and force feedback. The 1999 game Ape Escape<\/a> was the first to require a DualShock for play, and Sony quickly adopted the controller as the PlayStation standard, packing it in with subsequent versions of the console.The PlayStation 2<\/a> version of the DualShock was known as the DualShock 2<\/a>. Though its outward design remained the same (other than a shift from grey to black), the controller integrated pressure-sensitive face and shoulder buttons.Sony caused a stir prior to the release of the PlayStation 3<\/a>, first by showing a radically redesigned DualShock that many commentators derisively described as a boomerang<\/a>. The new design was either loved or hated by Playstation 3 followers. This design was scrapped before release, however.The original PlayStation 3 release saw the replacement of the DualShock with the SIxaxis<\/a>, an outwardly identical controller that inwardly lacked force feedback due to an ongoing lawsuit over the vibration copyright with hardware company Immersion. Instead, the Sixaxis featured an accelerometer that sensed motion input. Sony finally released a revised version of the SIxaxis that included force feedback support, not surprisingly dubbed the DualShock 3<\/a>, in 2008. The first software to support DualShock 3 technology was a demo of Gran Turismo 5 Prologue<\/a> which was released on the Japanese PSN <\/a>Store\u00a0on October 20, 2007. \u00a0Initially, the DualShock 3 controller was released in Japan on November 11, 2007 in black only and didn't reach North America until April 5, 2008 and Europe until July 2, 2008 (UK July 4, 2008). By this point, most existing PlayStation 3<\/a> titles had been updated to support the controller.\u00a0\u00a0The PS3 firmware v1.94 was released to add support for DualShock in PlayStation 3<\/a> titles and support for compatible PSOne<\/a>\u00a0and PlayStation 2<\/a> games was added later in v2.00.<\/p>","guid":"3000-1","id":1,"image":{"icon_url":"https:\/\/giantbomb1.cbsistatic.com\/uploads\/square_avatar\/0\/25\/10691-controleps22.GIF","medium_url":"https:\/\/giantbomb1.cbsistatic.com\/uploads\/scale_medium\/0\/25\/10691-controleps22.GIF","screen_url":"https:\/\/giantbomb1.cbsistatic.com\/uploads\/screen_medium\/0\/25\/10691-controleps22.GIF","screen_large_url":"https:\/\/giantbomb1.cbsistatic.com\/uploads\/screen_kubrick\/0\/25\/10691-controleps22.GIF","small_url":"https:\/\/giantbomb1.cbsistatic.com\/uploads\/scale_small\/0\/25\/10691-controleps22.GIF","super_url":"https:\/\/giantbomb1.cbsistatic.com\/uploads\/scale_large\/0\/25\/10691-controleps22.GIF","thumb_url":"https:\/\/giantbomb1.cbsistatic.com\/uploads\/scale_avatar\/0\/25\/10691-controleps22.GIF","tiny_url":"https:\/\/giantbomb1.cbsistatic.com\/uploads\/square_mini\/0\/25\/10691-controleps22.GIF","original_url":"https:\/\/giantbomb1.cbsistatic.com\/uploads\/original\/0\/25\/10691-controleps22.GIF","image_tags":"All Images"},"image_tags":[{"api_detail_url":"https:\/\/www.giantbomb.com\/api\/images\/3000-1\/?filter=image_tag%3AAll+Images","name":"All Images","total":21}],"name":"DualShock Controller","site_detail_url":"https:\/\/www.giantbomb.com\/dualshock-controller\/3000-1\/"},{"api_detail_url":"https:\/\/www.giantbomb.com\/api\/accessory\/3000-29\/","date_added":"2008-09-19 17:26:44","date_last_updated":"2013-05-25 20:24:21","deck":"The DualShock 3 is an updated wireless PlayStation 3 controller that incorporates rumble motors as well as motion-sensing SIXAXIS support.","description":"

Overview<\/h2>

The controller is a combination of technologies found in the DualShock 2 <\/a>and the SIXAXIS <\/a>controllers. It has the trigger-like L2 and R2 button modifications and motion sensors found on the SIXAXIS, and the rumble technologies similar to the DualShock 2's. It was unable to be released until over a year into the PlayStation 3<\/a>'s lifespan due to a lawsuit between the creators of the rumble <\/a>technology, Immersion, and Sony over their use of rumble in their previous controllers. After an out-of-court settlement, the DualShock 3 was announced and subsequently released. The DualShock 3 is also heavier, due to the new motors, which addresses a complaint of many about the SIXAXIS being too light.<\/p>

<\/p>

The DualShock 3 is available in a number of different colors; black, blue, red, pink, silver, white, jungle green, and a baseball stitching pattern.<\/p>

<\/p>

To see a list of PlayStation 3 games that support the SIXAXIS tilt functionality, see the SIXAXIS Support <\/a>concept page.<\/p>

Input<\/h2>
  • 2 analog sticks<\/li>
  • Directional D-pad (pressure sensitive)<\/li>
  • 3 digital buttons<\/li>
  • 8 pressure sensitive buttons<\/li>
  • 2 analog triggers<\/li>
  • Motion sensing around six axes<\/li><\/ul>

    Output<\/h2>

    The DualShock 3 controller is capable of communicating with a PS3 console via a tethered USB 2.0 connection, or wirelessly using Bluetooth.<\/p>

    <\/p>

    Firmware Requirements<\/h2>

    PlayStation 3: version 1.94 or higher<\/p>

    PlayStation or PlayStation 2: version 2.00 or higher<\/p>","guid":"3000-29","id":29,"image":{"icon_url":"https:\/\/giantbomb1.cbsistatic.com\/uploads\/square_avatar\/0\/495\/907335-dualshock3_screen_01_big.jpg","medium_url":"https:\/\/giantbomb1.cbsistatic.com\/uploads\/scale_medium\/0\/495\/907335-dualshock3_screen_01_big.jpg","screen_url":"https:\/\/giantbomb1.cbsistatic.com\/uploads\/screen_medium\/0\/495\/907335-dualshock3_screen_01_big.jpg","screen_large_url":"https:\/\/giantbomb1.cbsistatic.com\/uploads\/screen_kubrick\/0\/495\/907335-dualshock3_screen_01_big.jpg","small_url":"https:\/\/giantbomb1.cbsistatic.com\/uploads\/scale_small\/0\/495\/907335-dualshock3_screen_01_big.jpg","super_url":"https:\/\/giantbomb1.cbsistatic.com\/uploads\/scale_large\/0\/495\/907335-dualshock3_screen_01_big.jpg","thumb_url":"https:\/\/giantbomb1.cbsistatic.com\/uploads\/scale_avatar\/0\/495\/907335-dualshock3_screen_01_big.jpg","tiny_url":"https:\/\/giantbomb1.cbsistatic.com\/uploads\/square_mini\/0\/495\/907335-dualshock3_screen_01_big.jpg","original_url":"https:\/\/giantbomb1.cbsistatic.com\/uploads\/original\/0\/495\/907335-dualshock3_screen_01_big.jpg","image_tags":"All Images"},"image_tags":[{"api_detail_url":"https:\/\/www.giantbomb.com\/api\/images\/3000-29\/?filter=image_tag%3AAll+Images","name":"All Images","total":8}],"name":"DualShock 3","site_detail_url":"https:\/\/www.giantbomb.com\/dualshock-3\/3000-29\/"},{"api_detail_url":"https:\/\/www.giantbomb.com\/api\/accessory\/3000-30\/","date_added":"2008-09-19 17:27:13","date_last_updated":"2010-04-20 23:34:20","deck":"The DualShock 2 is Sony's standard controller for the PlayStation 2.","description":"

    The DualShock 2 was announced and released alongside the PlayStation 2<\/a>.\u00a0Apart from color, logo, and number of screws, it is visually identical to the original DualShock controller.<\/a>\u00a0Improvements over its predecessor include lighter weight, pressure sensitivity on the action buttons, and enhanced analog stick mobility.<\/p>","guid":"3000-30","id":30,"image":{"icon_url":"https:\/\/giantbomb1.cbsistatic.com\/uploads\/square_avatar\/0\/2164\/1270989-a_dual_shock_2.jpg","medium_url":"https:\/\/giantbomb1.cbsistatic.com\/uploads\/scale_medium\/0\/2164\/1270989-a_dual_shock_2.jpg","screen_url":"https:\/\/giantbomb1.cbsistatic.com\/uploads\/screen_medium\/0\/2164\/1270989-a_dual_shock_2.jpg","screen_large_url":"https:\/\/giantbomb1.cbsistatic.com\/uploads\/screen_kubrick\/0\/2164\/1270989-a_dual_shock_2.jpg","small_url":"https:\/\/giantbomb1.cbsistatic.com\/uploads\/scale_small\/0\/2164\/1270989-a_dual_shock_2.jpg","super_url":"https:\/\/giantbomb1.cbsistatic.com\/uploads\/scale_large\/0\/2164\/1270989-a_dual_shock_2.jpg","thumb_url":"https:\/\/giantbomb1.cbsistatic.com\/uploads\/scale_avatar\/0\/2164\/1270989-a_dual_shock_2.jpg","tiny_url":"https:\/\/giantbomb1.cbsistatic.com\/uploads\/square_mini\/0\/2164\/1270989-a_dual_shock_2.jpg","original_url":"https:\/\/giantbomb1.cbsistatic.com\/uploads\/original\/0\/2164\/1270989-a_dual_shock_2.jpg","image_tags":"All Images,Wiki"},"image_tags":[{"api_detail_url":"https:\/\/www.giantbomb.com\/api\/images\/3000-30\/?filter=image_tag%3AAll+Images","name":"All Images","total":6}],"name":"DualShock 2","site_detail_url":"https:\/\/www.giantbomb.com\/dualshock-2\/3000-30\/"},{"api_detail_url":"https:\/\/www.giantbomb.com\/api\/accessory\/3000-42\/","date_added":"2013-02-20 17:43:39","date_last_updated":"2015-12-19 16:55:33","deck":"The fourth iteration of the DualShock controller for PlayStation 4. It includes a touch pad, light bar, and Share button.","description":"

    Overview<\/h2>

    The DualShock 4 controller is Sony's first significant redesign since the DualShock <\/a>launched in 1997 as an updated controller for the original PlayStation. Sticking with the overall basic form factor, the DualShock 4 is a slightly larger, more ergonomic iteration on its predecessor. New features include a textured underside to improve grip, reshaped L2 and R2 buttons that better resemble analog triggers, reshaped left and right analog sticks that are concave on the top, a capacitive touch pad located where the start and select buttons were in previous versions, an built-in mono speaker, a headset jack, and a Move-styled, multi-color light bar. It has a built-in 3.65V Lithium-ion rechargeable battery with 1000mAh capacity.<\/p>

    <\/p>

    Input<\/h2>
    • Two analog sticks (Improved fidelity and materials over the DualShock 3)<\/li>
    • Pressure sensitive, four button D-pad<\/li>
    • Traditional \u0394, \u2610, O, X face buttons<\/li>
    • Two analog shoulder buttons (L1, R1)<\/li>
    • Two analog triggers (L2, R2)<\/li>
    • Face mounted 3-point clickable capacitive touch pad<\/li>
    • Two digital face buttons (Share, Options)<\/li>
    • Six-axis motion sensing (newly built high precision sensors)<\/li>
    • Headset jack (mono headset will be bundled with PS4)<\/li><\/ul>

      <\/p>

      Output<\/h2>

      The DualShock 4 has an in-built mono speaker \"to deliver high-fidelity sound effects\" from the controller and a 3 color LED light bar similar to the orb found in the PlayStation Move<\/a>.<\/p>

      <\/p>

      LED Light Bar<\/h2>
